title: 105_hr328
content: The Act titled "Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1997" prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1997 prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information. Section 2702(a)(1)(F) of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include genetic testing. Additionally, a new section, SEC. 2706, limits the collection and disclosure of genetic information. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act prohibits health insurance discrimination based on genetic information. It limits the collection and disclosure of genetic information by health insurance issuers and group health plans. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act requires authorization for disclosure of genetic information, with exceptions for criminal investigations or court orders. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act mandates authorization for disclosing genetic information, with exceptions for court orders, paternity establishment, medical diagnosis, blood relatives, and body identification. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act defines genetic information as information about genes, gene products, or inherited characteristics from an individual or blood-relative. It also defines genetic test as a test to determine genetic characteristics in an individual. Amendments include adding genetic testing to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The Genetic Information Health Insurance Nondiscrimination Act of 1974 is amended to include protection against the collection and disclosure of genetic information or genetic testing. SEC. 713. LIMITATION ON COLLECTION AND DISCLOSURE OF GENETIC INFORMATION. Limitation on Collection and Disclosure of Genetic Information: Health insurance issuers and group health plans are prohibited from requesting genetic information or genetic tests from individuals. Additionally, they cannot disclose genetic information without prior written authorization from the individual or their legal representative. Authorization is required for disclosing genetic information, including a description of the information, the recipient's name, and the purpose. Exceptions to disclosure restrictions include authorization under criminal laws or court orders. The disclosure of genetic information requires authorization, with exceptions for court orders, establishing paternity, medical diagnosis, identifying a body, and providing genetic information to blood relatives for medical purposes. The requirements of this section are considered a material modification for notice under a group health plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include definitions for genetic information and genetic tests. State laws described in the act shall not be superseded. Conforming amendments are also made. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include definitions for genetic information and genetic tests. Conforming amendments are made to sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include definitions for genetic information and genetic tests, with corresponding amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the collection and disclosure of genetic information. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include definitions for genetic information and genetic tests, with corresponding amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the collection and disclosure of genetic information. This includes a definition of genetic test as a test for determining genetic characteristics in an individual. SEC. 2752. LIMITATION ON COLLECTION AND DISCLOSURE OF GENETIC INFORMATION. Section 2706 provisions apply to individual health insurance coverage as they do to group health plans. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements. Amendments apply to group health plans starting January 1, 1998. The amendment made on January 1, 1998, applies to health insurance coverage in the individual market.
